Metal sites and acid sites in catalysts play an important role in promoting the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin derivatives. Herein, the review first summarizes the intrinsic role and synergy of metal and acid sites in the HDO of model compounds. Metal sites tend to be responsible for activating hydrogen donors and hydrogenation reactions, and acid sites are the main active sites for promoting C-O bond cleavage. Then, this review discusses the modulation methods of dual active sites, including the introduction of the second metal, the modification of support, and the modulation of structure. In addition, an overview of the HDO reaction mechanisms of the single model compounds (guaiacol, vanillin, phenol, etc.), the mixture of multiple model compounds and bio-oil are presented. Ring saturation reactions are easy to occur in the HDO of model compounds or bio-oil, but dehydroxylation is relatively difficult. Finally, proposals for sustainable upgrades using renewable hydrogen (alcohols, acids, water, etc.) are presented, as well as ways for modifying the catalyst structure to improve the water resistance of catalysts in aqueous phase. The possibility of in situ characterization to explore the reaction mechanisms in depth is illustrated, and the importance of using the mixture of model compounds and bio-oil as primary research objects are emphasized. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Bio-oil Model compounds Hydrodeoxygenation Metal sites Acid sites Catalysts Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In the last decade, the rapid depletion of fossil fuels has escalated the demand for renewable biomass as alternatives to chemicals and fuels [1]. Lignocellulose, as the main component of biomass, consists of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin [2,3]. Among these compounds, lignin is considered as the most abundant aromatic resource of nature, consisting of a large number of phenylpropane units [4,5]. Since lignin has abundant aromatic rings and oxygen-containing functional groups, some value-added chemicals can be produced through selective functionalization and defunctionalization. Moreover, most lignin-derived compounds have a lower oxygen content, and they are more suitable to be liquid fuels with a high energy density in comparison to fuels derived from other biomass components [6,7]. Lignin has several functional groups, including hydroxyl, carbonyl, and carboxyl groups, as well as unsaturated CC bonds. Through a rapid pyrolysis process, lignin can be converted into pyrolysis oil (bio-oil). However, bio-oil is difficult to be directly used as fuels due to its high oxygen content, low heating value and poor thermal stability [8]. Therefore, to improve the quality of bio-oil, a hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process needs be implemented to improve the ratios of H/C and C/O ( Fig. 1a). However, the complexity of bio-oil components and the repolymerization of phenolic compounds in thermal environments augmented the difficulty of exploring efficient catalysts and related reaction mechanisms. Currently, considerable research effort has been devoted to screening out efficient catalysts through using specific lignin model compounds as reaction substrates, which lay the foundation for the development of general catalysts for bio-oil HDO [9,10]. Guaiacol and vanillin are widely used as model compounds to investigate the HDO mechanism of bio-oil due to their large proportion in the cleaved lignin-oil, as shown in Fig. 1b [11,12]. Compared with bio-oil, the product distributions from HDO of guaiacol and vanillin are much clearer, which is helpful to explore the HDO reaction mechanism [13,14]. Furthermore, cyclohexane and 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP) derived from the HDO of guaiacol and vanillin can be used as biofuels, respectively, which are considered as alternatives to traditional fossil fuels [15,16]. Therefore, HDO is a fundamental process to produce high value chemicals and bio-oil upgrading, and the development of efficient catalysts is a key point. Up to now, several reviews on progress of lignin derivatives and bio-oil HDO reaction have been reported. Lu et al. summarized the role of single-atom catalysts in typical biomass value-adding reactions, with highly dispersed metal sites in the catalysts maximizing atomic efficiency [17]. Li et al. reviewed the electronic, interfacial and synergistic interactions between the two metals in bimetallic catalysts in the HDO reaction [18]. Compared with monometallic catalysts, the electronic modification between bimetals in bimetallic catalysts could change the original surface state of metal active sites and improve the performance of the catalysts. Chen et al., reviewed the HDO reactions of phenolic model compounds in bio-oils over various metal(s)/molecular sieves [5]. Mesoporous molecular used as support can confer catalysts with larger surface area and achieve better dispersion of metal and acid properties. Zhang et al., outlined the correlation the oxophilicity of catalysts and the performances in the HDO of phenolics [3]. Catalysts with moderate oxygenophilic can not only abstract the O from the phenolics, but also remove oxygen-containing functional groups easily with the help of active hydrogen. Wang et al. reviewed the characteristics and roles of the active sites of supported metal catalysts in the HDO reaction of lignin-derived phenolic compounds [19]. Active site alone is difficult to provide the desired product selectivity, and the intrinsic and synergistic effects of metal sites and acid sites are the key to determining catalyst activity. Thus, both metal sites and acid sites are important active sites in most of the reported catalysts and play crucial roles in HDO of lignin derivatives and bio-oil. Herein, the catalysts with metal-acid dual sites for HDO of lignin derivative was systematically reviewed in this work ( Fig. 2). The reaction mechanism of HDO reaction over metal sites and acid sites of catalysts was firstly introduced. It is worth noting that there are different interactions between dual active sites and reaction substrates/intermediates, which lead to differences in the products distribution. After that, the methods to regulate the dual metal-acid active sites were summarized, including changing the type of active metal and support and designing the coordination environment around the active center. Furthermore, we analyzed the reaction pathways and major product distributions during the conversion of single model compound, mixtures of model compounds, and bio-oils, and discussed the reaction mechanisms between dual-active sites and oxygen-containing functional groups. Finally, the progress and challenges of catalysts used in the upgrading of bio-oil and model compounds are summarized, and the perspectives for development of efficient catalysts for HDO reactions are presented. This review aims to elucidate the nature of the active sites and the reaction mechanism over the catalyst and provide insights for the design of green and efficient bio-oil conversion systems. 2 Hydrodeoxygenation mechanism 2.1 Reaction pathway Lignin-derived monomer compounds can be obtained from bio-oil by breaking the interunit C-O bonds and C-C bonds [20]. However, the production of monomeric compounds from bio-oil is extremely challenging due to the highly irregular polymeric structure and difficult-to-control properties, which limits the exploration of the HDO reaction mechanism of bio-oil [21]. Therefore, lignin model compounds were usually used as substrates in the HDO reaction to explore the reaction mechanism and screen efficient catalysts. Guaiacol is a commonly used model substrate in the HDO reaction, which possesses three types of C−O bonds: Calkyl−O, Caryl−OCH3, and Caryl−OH [22]. In addition, vanillin, a typical multifunctional aldehyde derived from lignin, is also used as a model compound to study the reaction mechanism over catalysts. Besides owing the same three types of C-O bonds as guaiacol, vanillin also has a CO double bond in the para position of the hydroxyl group [23]. Due to the different functionalities of these C-O and CO bonds, revealing the HDO mechanism of guaiacol and vanillin could pave the way for understanding the HDO of bio-oils. As aromatic compounds, guaiacol and vanillin not only have different oxygen-containing functional groups, but also have multiple unsaturated bonds in the benzene ring. Thus, HDO of aromatic oxygenates proceeds through two distinct pathways. One is that first hydrogenation is performed on the benzene ring. The saturation of the aromatic ring is conducive to weakening the strength of the C-O bond, and therefore the next step is hydrogenolysis of the C-O bond [24]. The second one is direct deoxygenation, in which the C-O bond is firstly cleavage and then the benzene ring is saturated by hydrogenation [25]. Direct deoxygenation is more likely to occur at high temperature and relatively low H2 pressure, since consumption of little H2 is considered to be the most favorable HDO reaction pathway [26]. In addition, competition and tandem reactions also occur during the HDO process and directly affect the product distribution. For example, there is a certain competitive adsorption of active hydrogen between the benzene ring and oxygen-containing functional groups, which will lower the selectivity of target products [27]. The cleavage of the C-O bond is usually associated with the acid sites of the catalyst. Oxygen vacancies, as a kind of Lewis acid sites, enhances the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for C-O bonds, which accelerates the cleavage of C-O bonds [28]. A series of catalysts have been used in the HDO of lignin-derived compounds and bio-oils. Active metals (such as Pt, Ru, Ni, Fe, Cu, etc.) and catalyst supports (such as transition metal oxides, mesoporous silica and carbon, etc.) constitute the main parts of catalysts [29–33]. Among them, active metals are mainly used for the activation of substrates and promote the hydrogenation reaction. The Ni-based catalyst has strong H2 dissociation ability, and the Cu-based catalyst has excellent hydrogen evolution activity in the system with alcohols as hydrogen donors. In addition, oxophilic metals represented by Fe and Mo have a strong affinity for oxygen atoms, which is conducive to deoxidation [31,32,34]. Catalyst supports with acid characteristics often promote the cleavage of C-O bonds, meanwhile, metal oxides with oxygen vacancies such as ZrO2 and TiO2 have selective adsorption and activation effects on reactants [29,30]. Therefore, the construction of catalysts with appropriate metal and acid dual active sites is crucial for upgrading bio-oil via HDO. 2.2 Role of metal sites Metal sites of catalysts play a crucial role on the HDO reaction. The hydrogen donor or H2 is first split into H atoms on the catalyst, and the dissociated H atoms are further adsorbed on the metal sites [35]. Then, the adsorbed H substances activate the reactants by hydrogen transfer. The activity of metal sites determines the production of active hydrogen and directly affects the distribution of hydrogenation products [36]. As shown in Table 1, for noble metal catalysts, Pd and Pt-based catalysts are conducive to the saturation of aromatic rings rather than the removal of phenolic hydroxyl groups, so cycloalkanes were the main products in the HDO of guaiacol. Contrary to Pd and Pt-based catalysts, Ru-based catalysts have appropriate hydrogenation activity, and the main products are aromatic compounds, phenol, and benzene, rather than aliphatic derivatives ( Fig. 3a). Fig. 3b-c showed that the absorption peak of the aromatic ring was significantly weakened with the formation of electron-rich Ru, which indicated that the electron-rich Ru inhibited the adsorption and activation of the guaiacol benzene ring [37]. Teles et al. investigated the effect of metal type on phenol HDO over silica-supported catalysts [38]. For the Pd/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts, the C-C bond on phenol was first hydrogenated and then dehydroxylated by hydrogenolysis ( Fig. 4a). In contrast, the direct dehydroxylation of phenol to benzene occurred over the oxophilic metal Ru (Ru/SiO2). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that O interacted more strongly with Ru than that with Pd and other metals, which favored direct deoxidation (Fig. 4b). Therefore, the activity of the metal itself and the binding affinity of the metal to oxygen are vital factors affecting the hydrogenation activity [39,40]. For non-noble metal catalysts, Ni, Fe, Co, Mo and Cu have been widely used in HDO reactions of lignin model compounds, where demethylation, demethoxylation, and deoxygenation occur simultaneously on the catalysts [56]. Ni-based catalysts have attracted much attention because of their excellent activity in HDO reactions, and the hydrogenation mechanism with preferential saturation of aromatic rings is similar to that over Pd and Pt-based catalysts. > 90% cycloalkanes yields were obtained over Ni-WOx/Al2O3, Ni2P/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and other Ni-based catalysts in the HDO of guaiacol [57–59]. Tai et al. used zeolite supported Ni catalyst for HDO reaction of guaiacol, and 97.52% guaiacol conversion were achieved [60]. The high dispersion of Ni and the accessibility between active metal and supports endowed the Ni/DHBeta catalyst with excellent HDO activity. However, part of the active metal Ni in the used catalyst was oxidized to NiO, resulting in the drop of guaiacol conversion (47.63%) after three consecutive runs of the catalyst. Though some Ni-based catalysts exhibited high HDO efficiencies, the oxidation of Ni active sites, coke deposition, and NiO contamination led to their poor stability [61,62]. Fe and Co species were able to effectively promote the cleavage of C-O bonds due to the strong oxophilicity [3]. Compared with Ni, Fe and Co are usually the second component of bimetallic catalysts, which is attributed to their relatively poor ability of H2 dissociation [19]. Hong et al. found that the introduction of Fe into Pd-based catalyst species could significantly improve the catalytic performance of HDO of m-cresol [63]. The Fe (110) surface produced a greater distortion of the adsorbed C-O bonds than the Pd (111) surface based on DFT calculations [64]. Shu et al. synthesized RuCo/SiO2-ZrO2 catalyst by co-precipitation method for HDO of guaiacol, and obtained 88% cyclohexane yield at 260 °C and 1 MPa H2 for 4 h [65]. The preferential adsorption and activation of oxygen-containing functional groups on Co avoids the preferential hydrogenation of aromatic rings. In addition to the strong interaction between Fe, Co species and oxygen-containing functional groups, the strong electron coupling effect between the bimetals could enhance the adsorption ability of the catalyst to the reaction substrate and the dissociation ability of H2. Mo and Cu-based catalysts show a poor affinity for CC bonds and high adsorption to C-O bonds, which are beneficial to the hydrogenation of oxygen-containing functional groups and the suppression of the hydrogenation of benzene rings [66,67]. Cai et al. prepared activated carbon-supported Mo-based catalysts for HDO of guaiacol and obtained more than 91% aromatics products at 300 °C and 3 MPa H2 for 3 h [52]. Wanmolee et al. revealed the surface phase changes of Cu3P/SiO2 catalysts by in situ X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) [68]. The XRD results showed that the CuHPO4·H2O precursor was transformed into Cu3P species with increasing reduction temperature. The Cu3P species are the main active sites for guaiacol and H2 activation, and the charge transfer between P and Cu contributed to the enhanced catalyst activity. Though non-precious metal catalysts have achieved some achievements in HDO of lignin model compounds, they required severer reaction conditions than noble metal catalysts. 2.3 Role of acid sites In addition to active metals, acid sites also play an important role in the HDO reaction. Acid sites with dehydration, hydrolysis and transalkylation capabilities are generally provided by the support. Moreover, the acid support can also disperse and stabilize the active phase in the catalyst. As presented in Table 2, catalysts supported on carbon supports, including Ni/AC (activated carbon), Mo/C, NiCo/CNT (carbon nanotubes) catalysts, have been widely used due to the stability of carbon support structure and the rich oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface [69–71]. As shown in Fig. 5a, Yu et al. prepared a series of porous carbon nanosphere supported Pd catalysts, and reported that the oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of carbon supports were considered as Bronsted acid sites, which promoted the cleavage of C-O bond of biomass derivatives [72]. A new peak at 1720 cm-1 in the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was ascribed to the CO vibrational stretching of the -COOH group, which further confirmed the existence of acid sites on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5b). Additionally, the Pd@APF-H2O2 (APF: 3-aminophenol-formaldehyde) catalyst possesses a much lower contact angle (CA) of = 8° after H2O2 post-treatment (Fig. 5d) in comparison to the Pd@APF (123°) (Fig. 5c). The increased surface oxygen-containing groups of carbon support improved the hydrophilicity and enhanced the dispersion of the catalyst in aqueous solutions. Nevertheless, the conversion of reactants over the catalyst with inert support did not complete due to the weak acidity, which led to a lack of deoxidation capacity of the catalyst. SiO2 and C support are inert supports, and nitric acid or hydrochloric acid was used to pretreat the support to increase the number of acid sites [27,73]. However, the use of strong acids may lead to the modification of the catalyst support morphology, which in turn resulted in an increase of reaction by-products [74]. In general, when the strength of catalyst acidity is weak, the HDO products of lignin derivatives are mainly incomplete deoxidization products. On the other hand, more side reactions would occur over the catalyst with excessive acidity, resulting in the decrease of the yield of the target product. Therefore, it is crucial to construct catalysts with suitable acid strength. Metal oxides have attracted much attention because of their suitable acidity as supports. Zheng et al. found that CeO2-ZrO2 had abundant oxygen vacancies, which acted as Lewis acid sites to improve the ability of the catalyst to adsorb oxygenates [88,89]. Tong et al. synthesized the Ni-Mn/Nb2O5 catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies for the HDO of guaiacol, and 72% cyclohexanol yield was obtained [90]. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) confirmed the existence of a large number of acid sites in the Nb2O5. Liao et al. synthesized the Au/Co3O4 catalyst for the HDO of vanillin, and the MMP yield reached 99% at 240 °C for 3 h [91]. As shown in Fig. 6a, the CO bond in vanillin was selectively adsorbed onto the surface of the Au/Co3O4 catalyst, and the active hydrogen directly reacted with the CO double bond in the vanillin to obtain MMP. The shift of XRD diffraction peaks and the appearance of characteristic electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) peaks confirmed that the metal oxide support was rich in acid sites (oxygen vacancies) (Fig. 6b-c). The DFT calculation results showed that the formation of oxygen vacancies as Lewis acid sites enhanced the adsorption capacity for CO bonds (Fig. 6d). Therefore, the metal oxides could improve the ability of the catalyst to adsorb oxygen-containing functional groups by providing stronger acid sites. In order to enhance the surface area and acidity of the catalyst, micropores (zeolite) and mesopores catalysts with strong surface tunability, such as SBA-16, TS-1, and HZSM-5 have been widely used in HDO reactions [84,92,93]. Zong et al. synthesized a defective zeolite carbon (CFR@HZSM-5) nanocomposite supported Pd catalyst for vanillin HDO [94]. The abundant acid sites in the composite catalyst replaced the acid additives in the inert catalyst systems. The stable and highly dispersed Pd particles endowed the catalyst with excellent HDO activity through strong electronic metal-support interactions. Although the unique pore structure could stabilize the metal species, it restricted the diffusion of substrate molecules into the channel to contact the active sites and the generation of the products [95]. In this regard, mesoporous materials and hierarchical zeolites have advantages. Mesoporous materials had the characteristics of high surface areas and porosity, which allowed reactant and intermediates to better access to active centers, enhancing the HDO reaction rate [5]. When hierarchical zeolites are used as support, they not only improved the accessibility to active sites, but also improved the dispersion of the metal active phases [96,97]. However, the zeolite-based support was rapidly deactivated due to the presence of H2O in the bio-oil [98]. As a by-product of the HDO reaction, the competitive adsorption of H2O on the active sites of the catalyst prevented the subsequent reactions from proceeding and reduced the yield of the target product [99]. Therefore, it was crucial to improve the water resistance of the catalyst with number of acid sites. 2.4 Synergistic effect In addition to the solo function of metal sites and acid sites, the synergistic effect between them is also crucial for the HDO of lignin derivatives. Catalysts with dual active sites have gradually become the mainstream in the HDO reaction attributed to the inherent activity and the interaction between dual sites. The total number of active sites, the balance between metal sites and acid sites, and the spatial distribution of each site in the catalyst are the key factors to determine the catalyst activity and product selectivity. Xu et al. showed that the synergistic effect between the metal sites and the acid sites in the CoMoS/ Nb2O5-γ-Al2O3 catalyst promoted the cleavage of C-O and C-C bonds of guaiacol, and the intermediate phenol converted to cycloalkane [100]. In addition, with the addition of Nb2O5 in the CoMoS/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the yield of benzene increased. It was due to the fact that the amount of Bronsted acid sites in the catalyst increased after introduction of Nb2O5, which promoted the breakage of C-O bonds. Concurrently, the addition of Nb2O5 enhanced the degree of sulfidation on the CoMoS, and Mo6+ was effectively converted to Mo4+ and Mo5+, which promoted the formation of the MoS2 phase on the catalyst and increased the active sites of the hydrogenation reaction. This enhanced the cleavage of the C-C bond and the intermediate product phenol was converted to cyclohexane. Ambursa et al. indicated that the excellent catalytic performance of Cu-Ni/Ti-MCM-41 catalyst in guaiacol HDO was attributed to the synergistic effect between active metal and support [55]. The Ti species were well-dispersed within the MCM-41 framework by a tetrahedral coordination into the MCM-41, which not only provided an amount of acid sites but also promoted the dispersion of CuO and NiO. The Cu-Ni metal sites were responsible for the activation and hydrogenation of H2, and the acid sites on the Ti-MCM-41 support were mainly responsible for the hydrogenolysis reaction. Therefore, modification of catalyst support could not only enhance the acidity of catalyst, but also promote the formation of active phase and improve the dispersion of metal sites on the supports. In addition to abundant metal and acid sites, the functional balance between metal sites and acid sites is also crucial for the improvement of catalyst performance. The favorable metal-acid balance is beneficial for the yield of the target product, which can be achieved by adjusting the appropriate ratio of metal sites to acid sites and controlling the nanoscale distance between two active sites. Yan et al. reported the effect of the functional balance of metal sites and acid sites on catalyst performance of Ni/Beta catalysts [101]. Moderately acid and highly dispersed Ni species distribution was achieved by adjusting the ratio of Ni to Beta, which enabled Ni/Beta catalysts to obtain 76% cyclohexane yield in the HDO reaction of guaiacol. Furthermore, Yan et al. also proposed two reaction pathways. In the dominant route, guaiacol initially underwent hydrogenation to 2-methoxycyclohexanol on metallic Ni sites, and then rapid demethoxylation and dehydroxylation of 2-methoxycyclohexanol to form cyclohexene. Finally, hydrogenation of cyclohexene to cyclohexane occurred on the metal sites. On the other hand, when the Ni content decreased in the catalyst, the guaiacol was first converted to 1,2-dimethoxybenzene and catechol on the acid sites. Then, the catechol rapidly underwent hydrogenation-dehydroxylation to form cyclohexane, and the 1,2-dimethoxybenzene slowly underwent the hydrogenation-demethoxylation to form cyclohexane. In addition to the inherent nature of metal and acid sites, the distance between active sites is another key factor to affect the HDO reaction. Chen et al. reported that the conversion of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene, the rate-limiting step in the phenol HDO process, had lower activation energy (TS2) over the Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst modified with 4-trifuoromethyl salicylic acid (TFMSA), as shown in Fig. 7a-c [102]. The nanoscale intimacy between Ru particles and acid sites over Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were the key to enhance the diffusion of intermediates between active sites. Ju et al. adjusted the distance between the metal sites and acid sites by controlling the pH value of the solution containing Pt precursor and Al2O3-ZSM-5 during the synthesis of the Pt/Al2O3-ZSM-5 catalyst [103,104]. As the pH value decreased from 5.4 to 2.5, the distance between the metal sites and the acid sites in Pt/Al2O3-ZSM-5 catalyst decreased from micrometer to nanometer scale. At the same time, the yield of hydrocarbons in the HDO of eugenol over the Pt/Al2O3-ZSM-5 catalyst increased from 21.4% to 40.8%. In summary, the synergistic interaction of dual active sites is beneficial to the production of active hydrogen and the conversion of intermediates, which enhances the performance of the catalyst with metal-acid sites. The synergistic effect between metal sites and acid sites over catalysts with dual active sites can not only improve the activity of catalysts, but also affect the distribution of products. The acid sites on the catalyst are the main active site to promote the C-O bond cleavage in the HDO of guaiacol and obtain low oxygen content products, such as phenol and catechol [105]. The acid strength of catalyst is related to the type of support. Normally, zeolite-based supports are rich in acid sites, and inert supports lack acid sites. Yan et al. synthesized Ru/ZSM-5 (possessing strong acid sites), Ru/Al2O3 (possessing weak acid sites), and Ru/SiO2 (absence of acid sites) catalysts for the HDO reaction of guaiacol to investigate the effect of catalyst acidity on product distribution [106]. With the decrease of catalyst acidity, the yield of cyclohexane decreased and that of 2-methoxycyclohexanol increased. This indicated that the products were mainly the high oxygen-content products when catalyst lacked acid sites. In addition, the substrate conversion was not complete due to insufficient production of active hydrogen, when the catalyst lacked metal sites [107]. Hence, abundant active sites are the prerequisite for high target product yield over catalysts. In general, the metal sites provide the active hydrogen and promote the saturation of the benzene ring, and the acid sites are mainly responsible for the dehydroxylation and demethoxylation. The synergistic interaction between the dual active sites significantly improves the hydrogenation and deoxidation capacity of the catalyst, and the reaction substrate is converted into low oxygen content products or complete deoxidized products. In addition to the natural properties of the active metal and the supports, oxygen vacancies formed by the strong electron transfer between the metal and the supports could also be used as active sites. It can improve the HDO reaction performance of the catalyst by changing the electronic and chemical properties of the catalysts surface [108]. It was observed that the formation of oxygen vacancies can substantially promote the yield of the target product [109]. This was due to the Lewis acid property of the oxygen vacancies, which is equivalent to their presence as acid sites [110]. Acid sites are generally considered to be the main sites for promoting C-O bond cleavage in lignin [111]. However, Zhang et al. found that Ru-MnO bimetallic sites in Ru-MnO/Al2O3 catalyst were highly active for selective hydrogenation of C-O bonds [112]. This is due to a large number of oxygen vacancies provided by MnO with embedded Ru, which enhanced the preferential vertical adsorption between lignin and catalyst and improved the selectivity of C-O bond cleavage. Therefore, catalysts with abundant oxygen vacancy can effectively adsorb oxygen-containing functional groups and then directly break the C-O bond, which significantly improves the performance of catalysts and changes the distribution of products. 3 Modulation approaches of dual sites 3.1 Second metals/promoters The introduction of the second metal is an effective method to improve the activity and stability of the catalyst. Some bimetallic systems, such as Ni-Co, Ni-Fe, and Cu-Ni catalysts showed high hydrogenation activity, since the incorporation of a second metal enhances the concentration and interaction of active sites over the catalyst [113–115]. Wang et al. synthesized the SBA-15 supported Al-doped Ni catalyst for the HDO of guaiacol via coprecipitating method using sodium aluminate (NaAlO2) as Al source ( Fig. 8a) [116]. NH3-TPD proved that the acidity of the catalyst was significantly enhanced after Al doping (Fig. 8b). The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) results showed that the reduction peaks of the catalysts after Al doping shifted to higher temperatures, which was attributed to the enhanced interaction between the Ni oxide species and the support (Fig. 8c). The excellent performance of the Ni/Al-SBA-15 catalyst was attributed to the abundant acid sites and suitable metal-support interactions. Han et al. prepared the Fe doped Ni/SiO2 catalysts by ammonia evaporation [117], and the formation of NiFe alloy in NiFe/SiO2 catalyst enhanced the adsorption of C-O bond on phenol. In addition, the introduction of Fe to the Ni-based catalyst would form the electronic defect of Ni, thereby weakened the adsorption of benzene rings on the catalyst surface. The Fe could be considered as an oxophilic metal to facilitate the adsorption of oxygen-containing functional groups. More importantly, the introduction of the second metal Fe could improve the stability of Ni-based catalysts, since the formation of bimetallic sites Ni-Fe was conducive to the stabilization of the electronic structure of active metals [114]. The introduction of a second metal in the Ni-based catalyst can improve the reusability of the catalyst by enhancing the interaction between active sites and supports. 3.2 Modification of support The modification of support can improve the stability of catalyst by changing the structure of catalyst. Generally, the bio-oil obtained from lignin pyrolysis has a high moisture content (typically 15–30 wt%) [118]. Concurrently, when metal-based catalysts are exposed to water at high temperatures, it may lead to rapid deactivation due to metal leaching and changes of structural properties [119]. The water resistance of the catalyst, meaning the likelihood of the catalyst deactivating in water, is a key factor in its application for bio-oil upgrading. Recently, nitrogen-doped carbon materials with abundant pore structures have been found to be the excellent supports. Nitrogen doping in the carbon skeleton was generally considered to be the active sites, which promoted the formation of the supports with small particle size and improved the water resistance of the catalysts [120]. Brandi et al. applied Ni/nitrogen-doped carbon (Ni/NDC) to vanillin hydrogenation in water [121]. The use of NDC as a support for Ni nanoparticles allowed the transfer of charge from Ni to the support in comparison with a pristine carbon support, which resulted in a higher water resistance ability of Ni. Han et al. prepared Ru supported on mesoporous TiO2 hollow spheres embedded with SiO2 nanoparticles catalysts (Ru-TiO2-SiO2) for hydrogenation of guaiacol in aqueous solutions [122]. Both the 100% conversion and 84.2% cyclohexanol yield were achieved under 1.5 MPa H2 at 160 °C. The high catalytic activity and good water resistance of the catalyst are mainly due to the unique spherical structure. This structure facilitated mass transfer, avoided the leaching of active metals, and improved the water resistance of the catalyst. Hence, the modification of the support could enhance the HDO activity of the catalyst in bio-oil with high water content by suppression of the metal leaching and structure damage. The modification of the support can not only change the structure of the catalyst but also obtain more active sites. Similar to N-doping, the catalysts pretreated with acid had more acid sites and showed better metal dispersion to enhance the performance of the catalysts [69]. Furthermore, the use of binary oxides as supports showed unexpected results. Guo et al. prepared Ru/Nb2O5-SiO2 catalysts via a sol-gel method and obtained desirable product yields (73.4–92.0%) in the HDO reaction of various lignin derivatives [123]. In the catalysts, SiO2 as the support endowed the catalyst with excellent specific surface area, and Nb2O5 acted as the main acid sites to promote the cleavage of C-O bonds. Zhang et al. prepared the SiO2-TiO2 binary compound as a support by liquid phase phosphidation using triphenylphosphine (PPh3), and a Ni2P/Ni12P5 mixed phase formed [124]. The XPS and experimental results showed that the electron transfer and synergy between the formed Si-O-Ti bond and Niδ--Ov-Ti3+ bond significantly enhanced the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Therefore, the modification of catalyst supports to improve the water resistance and the number of active sites of catalysts is an effective and feasible method. The modification of the support can improve the HDO activity of the catalyst in bio-oil with high water content. 3.3 Core-shell structure Generally, the structure of the catalyst affects the electron transfer between the active metal and the support. The core-shell structure acted as a bridge between the metal and the support, which enhanced the synergistic effect of the active components. In general, the core-shell structure is composed of active metal as the core inside the catalyst and metal oxide or active carbon with abundant pore size as the outer layer material [125–127]. As shown in Table 3 (Entry 3, 5 and 7), the catalysts with core-shell structure showed excellent catalytic performance in the reaction of HDO of model compounds and lignin. Yin et al. synthesized a core-shell Pd@Al-mSiO2 catalyst for phenol hydrogenation by one-pot method using K2PdCl4 as Pd source ( Fig. 9a) [128]. It was observed that the increase in the number of Lewis acid sites in the Al-modified mesoporous silica shell led to a cyclohexanone selectivity of 98.5%. Meanwhile, Pd/Al-mSiO2 was prepared as a reference, and after cycling experiments, it was found that the catalyst showed severe metal loss and certain degrees of Pd sintering, and the guaiacol conversion and cyclohexanone selectivity reduced more significantly. The results showed that the formation of a tight metal-acid interface in the core-shell structure enhanced the synergy of multiple active sites (Fig. 9b). Zhu et al. prepared Pd@CNFs (carbon nanofibers) catalyst for the hydrogenation of phenol by Pd support method [129]. The synergistic effect between the carbon nanofiber core and the derived shell carbon enhanced the adsorption capacity of Pd@CNFs catalyst for phenol, which led to the continuous hydrogenation of phenol and obtained 90.6% cyclohexanone. Moreover, the TiO2 supported Ni catalyst promoted the HDO reaction of guaiacol through the interfacial sites of the NiFe-FeOx core-shell structure [130]. The NiFe/TiO2 catalysts provided NiFeOx and FeOx-TiO2 interfacial sites due to the incorporation of Fe. Compared to Ni/TiO2 catalysts, the highly electron deficient sites existed on the FeOx-TiO2 interface, and the oxygen vacancies at the NiFeOx interface helped to immobilize the hydroxyl and methoxy groups in the guaiacol, which promoted their dissociation. In addition, the main products over the Ni/TiO2 were 2-methoxycyclohexanol (9.11%) and cyclohexanol (17.9%), and 87.9% selectivity to cyclohexanol was obtained over the NiFe/TiO2. It was shown that the abundant oxygen vacancies and highly dispersed active metal sites led to the high selectivity of the NiFe/TiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation reaction, which enabled the direct demethoxylation of guaiacol to obtain cyclic alcohols. Therefore, the core-shell structure was beneficial to improve the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. More importantly, it can ensure the accessibility of electron transfer between active sites [129]. 3.4 Discussion on catalysts design In general, the purpose of all the modulation approaches of dual sites is to improve the stability and activity of the catalyst, and finally to build a catalytic system that can efficiently upgrade bio-oil. Ni-based catalysts show great potential in HDO of lignin derivatives and bio-oil, which is due to its excellent hydrogenation capacity. However, the Ni-based catalysts may be oxidized in the HDO of bio-oil reaction, resulting in deactivation of the catalysts [60]. The introduction of the second metal can improve the stability of the Ni-based catalyst, which is attributed to the strong electron transfer between the metals. In addition, Ni-based catalysts lack the ability of hydrogen evolution to alcohols, while Cu species can activate alcohols [137,138]. Thus, when Cu is doped into Ni catalysts as the second metal, it endows the catalyst with the ability to convert alcohol hydrogen donor to active hydrogen, which expands the applications of Ni-based catalysts in HDO reactions [139,140]. In addition to the composition of the catalyst, the structure of the catalyst is also crucial for the catalytic performance, which affects the dispersion of the active sites. Since the catalysts with a core-shell structure have the large surface area and abundant pores, it promotes the distribution of active phase and ensures the accessibility between the active sites and the reactants [141]. But the shell of a typical core-shell structure is made of carbon supports, which lacks deoxidation capacity due to insufficient acid sites [129,142,143]. Compared to the inert carbon, metal oxides are considered as one kind of the most potential catalyst shell because of its abundant acid sites and strong deoxidation ability [144]. Moreover, the metallic oxide has abundant oxygen vacancies, which can adsorb oxygen-containing functional groups and provide reaction sites for the reactants. Thus, a core-shell catalyst with metal oxide as shell and bimetal Ni-Cu as core, could be one kind of the most promising catalysts for the HDO reactions in the future. 4 Applications in HDO of lignin derivatives 4.1 HDO of guaiacol Guaiacol is the preferred model compound extracted from bio-oil, which is the most widely studied. In the HDO of biomass derivatives and bio-oil, the key is the cleavage of C-O. The guaiacol molecule possesses three types of C-O bonds: CO-CH3, C-OCH3 and C-OH [69]. Among them, the C-O bond in CO-CH3 was easily cleaved via demethylation [145]. Therefore, guaiacol was generally demethylated to form catechol, and then the C-O bond linked to hydroxyl cleaved to obtain phenol, as shown in Fig. 10 [69,145]. The minor reaction routes were direct demethoxylation or first dehydroxylation followed by demethylation to phenol [146]. In addition, with the increase of reaction temperature and H2 pressure, the hydrogenation of aromatic ring was inevitable and even better than that of C-O bonds [147]. Here, after guaiacol converted to phenol via HDO, the products, including cyclohexanol, cyclohexene and cyclohexane, could be obtained via further hydrogenation of aromatic ring [148]. Another reaction route was that the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring firstly occurred to form 2-methoxycyclohexanol, and then cyclohexane was obtained through dehydroxylation and demethoxylation [149]. The distribution of products for the guaiacol HDO reaction is basically classified into two major groups: aromatic compounds and cycloalkane products. To date, a wide variety of catalysts for the guaiacol HDO have been reported, and metal oxide-supported nickel catalysts were considered to be the most promising catalysts due to the highly dispersion of active sites and good stability [150]. Based on previous reports, nickel-based catalysts were also the best non-precious metal catalysts for the generation of cycloalkane products [58,151]. Zhang et al. developed a highly stable bifunctional catalyst (Ni-Co/NbOx) for HDO of guaiacol, and the conversion of guaiacol and the yield of cycloalkane were 100% and 98.9%, respectively [152]. Both the high dispersion of Ni-Co alloy and the strong oxophilicity of NbOx endowed the excellent performance of the catalyst. Han et al. reported different HDO of guaiacol reaction pathways over Co/ZrP and Ni/ZrP catalysts [153]. Cyclohexane was obtained from guaiacol over the Co/ZrP catalyst through HDO of phenol intermediate (PHE route). On the contrary, guaiacol was preferentially hydrogenated on the benzene ring over the Ni/ZrP catalyst, and then the intermediate 2-methoxycyclohexanol was further deoxygenated to obtain cyclohexane (2-M route). The supply of active hydrogen was the main factor determining the reaction pathway, and the stronger hydrogen evolution capability of Ni-based catalysts favored the more H2-consuming 2-M route. Currently, most guaiacol HDO catalysts have low selectivity to aromatics because of the presence of the aromatic rings hydrogenation, and thus over-hydrogenation occurs [10]. Compared to cycloalkanes, arenes have higher octane number and can be directly used as transportation fuels [9]. Wang et al. prepared the Ru/Ti-SiO2 catalysts with abundant Ti3+ defects and size-controllable Ru particles by wet impregnation method [46]. Among them, Ti-modified SiO2 support promoted the formation of defect-rich TiOx species, which improved the dispersion of Ru particles. Also, the Ru0-Ti3+ interface on the catalyst facilitated the activation of the C-O bond. Thus, a high conversion (83.6%) and phenol selectivity (70.4%) were obtained for HDO of guaiacol. Camila A. Teles et al. investigated the effects of different support loaded metal Pd on guaiacol HDO [154]. It was found that phenol was further converted to cyclohexanone over the SiO2 and CeO2-based catalysts, while only benzene was detected over the ZrO2, TiO2 and Nb2O5-based catalysts. This was due to the presence of oxygenophilic cations, where hydroxyl groups were strongly adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, blocking the catalytic sites, and thus inhibiting the further conversion of phenol. 4.2 HDO of vanillin Vanillin is a model biomass phenolic compound derived from lignin. Vanillin mainly contains three functional groups, including carbonyl, hydroxyl and ether bond [155]. Vanillin HDO usually involves hydrogenation of the CO double bond on the aldehyde group of Vanillin to 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methoxyphenol followed by hydrogenolysis to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol ( Fig. 11a) [15]. Then 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol was demethoxylated to form 4-methylphenol, and 4-methylphenol was more prone to aromatic ring saturation to obtain naphthenic compounds. Similar to guaiacol, 4-methylphenol tended to undergo ring hydrogenation to methylcyclohexanol with increasing temperature and hydrogen pressure. Finally, methylcyclohexanol was dehydroxylated and hydrogenated to obtain the final product methylcyclohexane [81,156]. However, the reaction temperature usually required > 300 °C for HDO of vanillin to be completely deoxygenated due to the large steric hindrance of the three oxygen-containing functional groups [156]. Therefore, 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol was the main product at relatively low temperature. The HDO of vanillin were studied over a variety of supported metal catalysts. The metal sites and acid sites of the catalyst are crucial for the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of vanillin [157]. Zhang et al. prepared the Ni/Nb2O5 catalysts for the hydrogenation of vanillin to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol [158]. The experimental results and related characterizations confirmed that Ni nanoparticles were responsible for the hydrogenation of vanillin to 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methoxyphenol, and the acid sites were crucial for the hydrogenolysis of 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methoxyphenol to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol. In addition, the enriched Ov on the catalyst adsorbed and activated the C-OH bond in 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methoxyphenol, leading to the reduction of the dissociation energy. In the case of bifunctional catalysts with metal and acid sites, the relative balance of metal sites and acid sites was also an important factor affecting the HDO of phenolic compounds. Kim et al. explored the effect of the balance of metal sites and acid sites on the HDO of vanillin by adjusting the metal/acid ratio on Ru/HZSM-5 catalysts [159]. When the proportion of HZSM-5 was too high, the excessively strong catalyst acidity would promote the cleavage of the Caryl-C bond, resulting in the conversion of methylcyclohexane to cyclohexane and the loss of carbon. The aromatic ring became saturated and cycloalkanes were the main reaction products, when the load of Ru exceeded 5 wt%. Finally, 93.6% cycloalkane yield was obtained over Ru (5 wt%) /HZSM-5 (Si/Al=23) catalyst. Therefore, the balance of metal sites and acid sites determines the product distribution and improves the performance of the catalyst. 4.3 HDO of other model compounds In addition to guaiacol and vanillin, phenol, m-cresol and eugenol are often used as bio-oil model compounds to screen high-efficiency catalysts and reveal the reaction mechanism of bio-oil HDO [160–162]. Similar to the mechanism of guaiacol and vanillin HDO, metal sites tended to be responsible for activating hydrogen donors and hydrogenation reactions, while acid sites were the main active sites for promoting C-O bond cleavage (Fig. 11b-d). Tang et al. synthesized Ni/SAPO-11 with different Si/Al for HDO of phenol [163]. The conversion of phenol over Ni/SAPO-11 (Si/Al=0.3) catalyst was 97.5%, and the yield of cycloalkane reached 94.0%. Under the optimal process, the Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst was applied to the hydrogenation of bio-cracking oil. The tandem reaction of catalytic dehydration over molecular sieves and hydrogenation over Raney nickel, which promoted the conversion of cracked oil into upgraded oil with high calorific value. Singh et al. reported the excellent activity of Ru-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst for the HDO of m-cresol and eugenol [164]. The strong interaction between Ru nanoparticles and N atoms, and the suitable acidity on the SiO2-Al2O3 support enhanced the catalytic performance of the Ru-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the aromatic rings of all lignin derivatives were successfully transformed and the corresponding products with high selectivity were obtained in the hydrogenation of bio-oil over Ru-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. 4.4 HDO of pyrolysis oil and mixtures Bio-oil is a complex assembly composed of various organic compounds. In order to understand the bio-oil HDO reaction mechanism and select suitable catalysts, a single model compound or a mixture of multiple model compounds was usually selected for catalytic performance evaluation. Funkenbusch et al. reported the HDO of a mixture of anisole, m-cresol and phenol over the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [165]. The mixture occurred ring saturation, demethylation and dehydroxylation reaction over Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. The mixture did not undergo secondary reactions due to weak interactions, but the mixture exhibited competitive adsorption to the active sites of the Pt/Al2O3, resulting in the decrease of catalytic performance. Zhang et al. investigated the effect of Ru/C catalyst on the quality of upgraded oil under the condition of formic acid as the hydrogen source [166]. After HDO upgrading, the oxygen content of the modified oil was significantly lower than that of the original cracked oil. The esterification and ketoneization of acid compounds resulted in a great decrease of the total acid number (TAN) and corrosiveness of the upgraded oil. The appearance of aromatics and hydrocarbons indicated that the calorific value of the modified oil significantly increased. Alkyl-methoxyphenol model compounds are often used to study the HDO reaction mechanism of bio-oil over catalysts because of the similar functional group composition to bio-oil [130]. HDO of alkyl-methoxyphenol mixtures over Ni2P/TiO2 catalysts at 300 °C and 4 MPa H2 was investigated and 87% naphthenic yields was obtained [167]. The higher HDO activity of Ni2P/TiO2 catalyst than that of Ni/TiO2 was attributed to the synergistic effect of metal sites and acid sites in the catalyst and the high dispersion of active metals after P modification. More importantly, 37.4% hydrocarbon fuel yield was obtained under optimal reaction conditions using the Ni2P/TiO2 catalyst. For bio-oil, one of the most important issues is to reduce the acidity, since high acidity of bio-oil could lead to the catalyst deactivation. Hydrotreating bio-oil under mild conditions using supported metal catalysts is an effective way to reduce acid value. Choi et al. reported the hydrotreatment experiment of reduced the acid value of bio-oil by using TiO2-supported metal catalysts [168]. Although TiO2-supported Ni, Co and Cu catalysts exhibited esterification and hydrogenation activities, the acid value of bio-oil did not change significantly. Notably, unlike the corresponding monmetallic catalysts, the acidity of bio-oil was significantly reduced by reducing the contents of carboxylic acids, aldehydes and aromatic compounds over the Ru-doped bimetallic catalysts (RuNi/TiO2 and RuCo/TiO2). In addition, bio-oils prepared by the two-step HDO method have higher H/C ratio and higher thermal stability than those prepared by the one-step HDO method [167]. The first step was the thermal pretreatment of the bio-oil dissolved in solvent without catalyst, which yields a mixture consisting of alkyl methoxyphenol, eugenol, and other low-oxygen compounds [130]. The phenolic compounds, carboxylic acids and carbonyl groups converted into alcohols and esters after pretreatment of the bio-oil, which effectively reduced the amount of acid in the bio-oil [169]. Therefore, pretreatment of bio-oil is a promising method to reduce the difficulty of bio-oil HDO reaction and improve the stability of bio-oil during storage. 5 Conclusions and perspectives This review summarized the HDO reactions of model compounds and bio-oils from the perspective of catalyst metal sites and acid sites. It is evident from the reviewed literature that the construction of high-efficiency catalysts with metal and acid dual-active sites was the key for the HDO reaction and upgrade of lignin derivatives to biofuels and value-added chemicals. Among them, metal sites were mainly responsible for the activation of substrates and hydrogen donors, and the acid sites were responsible for promoting the cleavage of the C-O bonds. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst, including composition, porosity, dispersion of the active phase, number and strength of acid sites, and electronic interactions between the metal and the support, affected the performance of the catalysts. In addition, this review discusses the modulation methods of dual active sites, including cooperative modification and morphological control. Secondly, the basic HDO reaction pathways and proposed catalytic mechanisms for various model compounds (guaiacol, vanillin, phenol, etc.) were summarized to understand the reaction mechanism of bio-oil HDO. Translating the HDO mechanistic understanding of model compounds into real bio-oils was exacerbated by the complexity of the different components in bio-oils. Though the complete and accurate HDO reaction mechanism of real bio-oil remained unclear, the saturation of the benzene ring and the cleavage of the C–O bond were the main HDO pathways. Based on the above content, some suggestions for exploration of the HDO mechanism and construction of efficient catalysts are put forward. (i) Alcohols and acids derived from lignin have been used as hydrogen sources in the HDO of hydroxymethylfurfural [170]. The development of catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions with alcohols and acids as hydrogen donors instead of H2 is highly desirable to reduce transportation and storage costs. However, it is rarely used in HDO with bio-oil and lignin model compounds as reaction substrates until now, which may be due to the lack of enough active hydrogen content provided by alcohols and acids. Therefore, it is necessary to construct catalysts with stronger hydrogen evolution capacity to provide enough active hydrogen content in the HDO of bio-oil. (ii) As a green solvent, water has a lower cost than organic solvents and has been used in HDO reactions [171]. However, it would bind to the active sites on the surface of the catalyst when the water molecules adsorbed on the catalyst [172]. In this way, the catalyst is inactivated due to the lack of active sites. Therefore, the hydrophobic shell could be constructed on the core of catalysts to enhance the hydrophobicity of the catalyst, which is hence of crucial importance for improving the stability of catalysts in water. (iii) Ni catalysts have excellent hydrogenation activity in HDO reaction, but their stability is poor and lack of hydrogen evolution ability for hydrogen donors of alcohols. The introduction of Cu can improve the activity and stability of Ni-based catalysts due to the electron transfer between Ni and Cu. In addition, the core-shell structure acted as a bridge between the metal and the support, enhancing the synergistic effect of metal-acid dual sites in the catalyst. Therefore, a core-shell catalyst with metal oxide as shell and bimetal Ni-Cu as core, could be one kind of the most promising catalysts for upgrading bio-oil. (iv) A thorough understanding of the mechanism of interaction between the catalyst and the functional groups is required. Generally, the electronic properties and morphology of active sites change during the reaction proceeds, which directly affects the selectivity of products. In this regard, in situ characterizations can be used to reveal active sites changes and interactions with functional groups, especially in HDO without the use of H2. (v) The stubbornness, high acidity and complexity of bio-oil often lead to the repolymerization of products and the deactivation of catalysts. Pretreatment can convert phenolic compounds, carboxylic acids and carbonyl groups in the bio-oil to alcohols and esters, which is favorable for the following upgrading of bio-oil. (vi) The model compounds (guaiacol and vanillin) are still the main research objects, which is not in line with practical application. More exploration should be carried out on the mixture of model compounds and real bio-oil, which is conducive to the industrial application. coredata.dc:description: Metal sites and acid sites in catalysts play an important role in promoting the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin derivatives. Herein, the review first summarizes the intrinsic role and synergy of metal and acid sites in the HDO of model compounds. Metal sites tend to be responsible for activating hydrogen donors and hydrogenation reactions, and acid sites are the main active sites for promoting C-O bond cleavage. Then, this review discusses the modulation methods of dual active sites, including the introduction of the second metal, the modification of support, and the modulation of structure. In addition, an overview of the HDO reaction mechanisms of the single model compounds (guaiacol, vanillin, phenol, etc.), the mixture of multiple model compounds and bio-oil are presented. Ring saturation reactions are easy to occur in the HDO of model compounds or bio-oil, but dehydroxylation is relatively difficult. Finally, proposals for sustainable upgrades using renewable hydrogen (alcohols, acids, water, etc.) are presented, as well as ways for modifying the catalyst structure to improve the water resistance of catalysts in aqueous phase. The possibility of in situ characterization to explore the reaction mechanisms in depth is illustrated, and the importance of using the mixture of model compounds and bio-oil as primary research objects are emphasized.
coredata.dc:title: Catalysts with metal-acid dual sites for selective hydrodeoxygenation of lignin derivatives: Progress in regulation strategies and applications
